characters: SHE RAISES HER SHIRT AND FLASHES HER BREASTS, SCREAMING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CREDITS ROLL OVER ‘GIRL ON THE STREET’ INTERVIEWS done on a cheap video camera in various locations around Chagrin Falls, Ohio (population 6,500, an hour south of Cleveland): A TEEN GIRL #1 speaks into the camera, playing with her hair as she tries not to giggle.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: Mostly, girls just hook up with guys at parties, but usually it’s with someone they know, like a friend. I mean, it’s not like I hear people saying I’m saving myself for marriage or anything. She giggles and we cut to a TEEN GIRL #2, this one scrunching her face into her turtleneck, to hide her identity. Her friends mill in the background.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: The point of being young is to experience a bunch of people so you know what you want. In a few more years I’1l be able to tell a good one from a bad one.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD GIRL
dialogues.text: (yelling out) And the big ones from the little ones. Another teen laughs, revealing her face and we cut to a TEEN GIRL #3 who has her hair cropped close. She speaks directly at the camera, dangerously close to the lens.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: They’re nasty sluts. And slutty girls become slutty women and then they marry nasty guys, who drive gross cars and smell like cheap beer. A TEEN GIRL #4 pushes the Teen Girl #3 aside and screams:

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: Is this like those Girls Gone Wild? Are you from MTV?

dialogues.speaker: SHE RAISES HER SHIRT AND FLASHES HER BREASTS, SCREAMING
dialogues.text: TEEN GIRL #4 (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: WHOOOO
dialogues.text: The screen freezes. The title  11/4/05 2. Normal Adolescent Behavior Appears over her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: Gary Glitter sings his raunchy “Do You Wanna Touch Me” Late Summer in Chagrin Falls, Ohio about forty minutes south of Cleveland. WENDY BERGMAN (senior, 17, beautiful but not ready to accept it) walks through the “Coop” private school grounds; she leads us under banners that say “WELCOME NEW CLASS” and “DON’T DIS THE ORIENTATION -- HAVE FUN AND WELCOME!” It all feels like it could be the Summer of Love except for the girls are wearing Seven jeans and the guys are wearing vintage and everyone’s hair is done, even the ‘alternative’ kids. Wendy passes by as a group of fifty students does a ‘lap sit’ -- they stand in a circle and then sit down at the same time. Eventually they fall amid general hysterical laughter. If Wendy wasn’t rolling her eyes before, she certainly is now. ACROSS THE QUAD we meet BILLIE (17, short blond hair and vintage clothes, hottest girl in school according to current web polls). She is walking towards Wendy; she is blond to Wendy’s brunette, intelligent enthusiasm to Wendy’s brilliant sarcasm. They are a perfect match for each other. A car pulls up quickly between them as they near the parking lot. It squeals to a stop and SEAN MAYER (17, tall with good looks that skew slightly pretty) gets out of the car. The car squeals away. If it looks like the opening of the Breakfast Club, well, all the better. He skulks towards the orientation festivities but he also steals a glance at Wendy. Billie yells out to Wendy:

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Woman! Wendy jogs the last few feet to her best friend and then they join the rest of the group. Besides Billie there is ANN, Chinese with a defiant red streak in her hair; JONAH a stoner reading a Miles Davis biography;  11/4/05 3. ROBERT, tall and the most conventionally good looking of the unconventional group and PRICE who has blond hair and blue eyes and wants desperately to fit in. Which is why he pulls out, and places on his head, a TRUCKER’S CAP. The GROUP GROANS.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You should burn that hat.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: It’s plastic. Toxic fumes?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: He could burn a little of it Symbolically. She jumps up, fishing a lighter from her bag. She hands the hat and the lighter to Price.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do it. Show us you’re better than the hat. The group looks at Wendy, asking for permission.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Burn a little. It’1ll be good for you. Price burns a little of the hat, sheepishly, and the group all cheer. Price leans over to hug the girls and it quickly turns into a wrestling/play fight. Wendy looks up and sees a FRESHMEN GIRL and guy whispering and looking at the group’s antics. Wendy stands up, brushing herself off. WENDY (CONT’D) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: (to the Freshmen) Can we help you? The rest of the group get up as well, looking slightly sheepish, except for Billie. The Freshmen stand there, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: What?!  11/4/05 4. Freshmen Girl points to Wendy’s necklace, which reads “Hoochie”.

dialogues.speaker: FRESHMAN GIRL
dialogues.text: I like your necklace. The two laugh and walk away. Wendy touches her necklace, stung.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Okay! I think we’ve successfully oriented ourselves. Billie? Billie stands up, and the group gathers their things.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) Are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (motioning out to the field) Can’t. My brother’s here.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Call me later?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Frigging right. All six hug, with real warmth. Somebody yells out to them from a passing car.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT IN CAR
dialogues.text: Kiss. Kiss. Kiss! Wendy and Billie roll their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Seriously, when did being a lesbian become cooler than blowing a rock star?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You’ve never blown a rock star.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Neither have you.  11/4/05 5. They laugh. The other four are a little ways away, but Billie hangs on to Wendy for a second.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: What if you could blow a rock star?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: And ruin what we have? Billie slaps Wendy’s ass.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: That’s my girl. Wendy waves at Billie as she joins the others and walks off. Wendy is all alone outside the school. She wanders around, kicking a few pebbles, she picks a leaf froma tree and starts humming the theme to “The A-Team.” Wendy goes back inside the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school is empty, a little eerie. Still humming, Wendy heads towards the classrooms, which are all ina large hangar type building -- each classroom is divided with partitions into a “bay”. In the center is a library and at the far corner, a SCIENCE classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the science area, Wendy opens a door removing ETHANOL. Pouring the ethanol into a wide-mouthed beaker she places the leaf in the ethanol, lights a Bunsen burner and lets the leaf start to boil in the solution. Sean watches, unseen by Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Blowing up the school? Wendy tries to act cool.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Did you follow me in here?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I wanted to get the lay of the land. Plus I hate that song.  11/4/05 6. Sean hums the “A-Team” theme back. Wendy is caught for a second, then comes right back at him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: The “lay of the land”.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I’m new. I figured I could, I dunno, memorize where everything was.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: There’s not much to memorize. She turns him around and points out the “landmarks” of school.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are the classrooms. No walls, so you have to have respect for everyone. That’s a big word around here -- respect. Make sure you use it inappropriately.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Like irony.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That would be “incorrectly.” Wendy points out some more places in the school.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the library. We gather in the lounge for announcements every Thursday for Community Meeting; better known as “where people bitch about the lack of respect in the public bathrooms”.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You’re not blowing anything up, are you? Wendy turns back to her leaf.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Get the lights. She gestures to the other side of the room. Sean runs to the switch, hits it. The sun has started to set, so the room is relatively dark. Wendy turns the Bunsen burner off. The leaf GLOWS BRIGHT RED.  11/4/05 7. WENDY (CONT’D) I just read about it and I wanted to try it. The electrons in the leaf are ‘excited’. They have these names that are so... Human. Excited. Lazy. Aggressive. Did you know they can be “impure”?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You couldn’t try it during school?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I hate chemistry.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: But She puts her finger to her lips.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Your secret’s safe. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Who would you tell? He’s stung, but hides it.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: My mom’s a chemist. I would never make fun of you for liking this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (indignant, he’s hit close to home ) If you did I’d kick your ass.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: If I did it would be ironic.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That’s incorrect.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Kicking my ass would be inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No, but it would be disrespectful.  11/4/05 8. A pause as she looks at Sean. He smiles at her. She tries not to smile back but she does.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wendy! The lights blaze on, and the leaf stops shining red. Sean and Wendy move apart, quickly. At the other end of the room is NATHAN BERGMAN (15, he recently grew about six inches, now he’s a taller version of his gawky old self).

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: My brother, Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Can we go home already? Wendy dumps out the ethanol and leaf, and walks away from Sean, who quickly follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy’s car pulls into a driveway, on the left, a large Tudor house, on the right, a similarly sized brick home with a much less well-tended yard. INT. WENDY’S CAR - DAY Sean sits in the passenger seat, Nathan’s in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (points left) This is me.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (points right) That’s me.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You know?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Have you read “The Watchmen”?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You knew who I was?  11/4/05 9. Sean keeps his eyes on Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, I saw you, you know, around. I didn’t know who you were.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: So you read it? Because I have all of them. If you wanna, you know, read them or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l read them.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m going in, okay?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You could come over...ask my mom about impure electrodes or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m good. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (super eager) Or you could come over to our house tomorrow? You can read them then.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. Nathan grins, thrilled. Wendy watches Sean as he gets out and goes into his house. Nathan is already at their front door.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: You have the keys! Wendy sighs and gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Why’d you ask him over for Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Why not? Wendy doesn’t answer. FADE TO BLACK. LEGEND: This Is Saturday  10 14 12 13 11/4/05 10. INT. JONAH’S HOUSE: ROOM - DAY 7 Zippy, happy pop music plays as we see our group get ready for Saturday night in their own homes on a Saturday afternoon. Jonah fixes his hair, takes a long pull on a bong, refixes his hair and then puts on a Cleveland Indians baseball hat. INT. ANN’S HOUSE: ROOM - DAY 8 Ann sits on her bed, which is surrounded by posters that have inspirational sayings, like “Hang In There, Baby,” and “God Will Provide, But It Helps To Study”. Ann brushes her hair, tries out pigtails, then a ponytail, then scrunches it around so it covers her face. INT. PRICE’S HOUSE: ROOM - DAY 9 Price reads a copy of RAYGUN while he is lifting weights. INT. BILLIE’S HOUSE: ROOM - DAY 10 Billie applies lip liner, fills it in and then blots. She does it again. And again. INT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: BATHROOM - DAY 11 Robert showers, singing loudly along to the pop song we hear. INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: WENDY’S BATHROOM - DAY 12 And finally Wendy, who is in her bathroom, sitting in the tub though there is no water in it, as she absentmindedly drums her fingers. INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: NATHAN’S ROOM - EVENING 13 Nathan sits poised in his room, when the doorbell rings and he springs to life and runs out  14 15 11/4/05 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan sprints down the stairs and runs to answer it. Downstairs, Sean is waiting for Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Hi! (trying to be cool) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (he holds the comics up) I brought these. If you want to read them.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Great. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: So thanks for inviting me.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: We’re neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan has carefully prepared a tray of food, which is waiting for them. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Holy shit. My mom can barely make pop tarts.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh I made it.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: For me?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean, I don’t get many guys, I mean people, you know...

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. No. That’s cool.  16 11/4/05 12. Sean takes an involuntary step back.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: No... I mean, I like to cook, so it isn’t like. I mean, like I didn’t plan everything, it’s not a trap. Here. Look, see these, these are really easy to make - - Nathan grabs a cookie off the tray and hands it to Sean but as he does, he trips on his own feet, he tumbles towards Sean and his hand ENDS UP ON SEAN’S CROTCH. There is a moment where Nathan doesn’t know what to do. His hand actually stays there he’s so confused. Sean moves away and Nathan stands up and does what anyone would do; he runs out. Sean goes after him. INT. BERGMAN’S HOUSE: WENDY’S ROOM - NIGHT 16 The girls are hanging out, talking about Sean.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He’s from Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: So he transferred as a senior?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I guess. People transfer.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: In third grade people transferred. We’ve had the same people in our classes forever.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: He seems a little too Queer Eye and not enough Straight Guy.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (a little too quickly) He’s not. He’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He was nice to Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Your brother is easy to be nice to. Like puppy dogs and homeless people.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Billie!

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I’m not the one making him out like Sean the Saint.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (the peacekeeper ) If we were normal girls, we’d be fighting over him. Fresh meat.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Thank god we’re not normal. Wendy goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m getting a pop.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: For me too.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wendy shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy is getting three Diet Cokes from the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dammit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy walks toward the voice, seeing Sean in the back foyer, standing in front of an open garbage can. He has an apple core, which he can’t throw away because the garbage is overflowing.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was supposed to take that out.  19 11/4/05 14.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey. Wendy takes glances quickly above her, as if Billie and Ann could see her right now. But they can’t, so:

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’1l get it. Wendy takes the garbage bag out of the garbage and ties it shut.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You need help?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Sure. He takes the bag and follows her to the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk to the six trashcans that line up on the property line between their houses. Sean’s backyard is littered with boxes. Wendy opens a trashcan and Sean places the bag inside. As he does, his hand touches hers for a moment, and she catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You were sweet to come by.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Nathan’s weird. But potentially very cool.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He’s temporarily weird. Proof that phases are real. Wendy absently wipes her hand on her pants.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Is your hand okay?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Huh? Yeah. You know when you touch something gross? Sean looks down at his own hand.  11/4/05 15.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughs) Oh god, no -- not you. I’m sorry. I meant the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Oh. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I should go in. They don’t move, just stand there for another moment.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You’re kinda weird, too.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Amazing line. Brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: And how do you know it’s a line? He steps closer to her, thinking about kissing her

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well, if you’re calling me weird in earnest, that’s pretty mean.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (quiet) So you’re hopeful I’m trying to pick you up.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Pick me up? What are you from, 1976?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You’re funny.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Clever. Funny. Smart. You like science.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Those are all words that mean ugly.  20 21 22 11/4/05 16.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You are definitely not ugly. You’re just pretty and smart. Wendy has nothing to say to this. They move closer to each other so that they are almost kissing, but they don’t touch.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can’t-- I mean, I’m not...

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (not moving) I’m not available. If you didn’t find that out at orientation, you’1l definitely find it out soon. From in front of the houses the sound of a horn honking interrupts them; Sean and Wendy stay still for one moment longer, but then Sean realizes who it is.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Sean leaves Wendy standing there. She waits until he is gone and then sprints inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy grabs the three Diet Cokes, frantic, almost dropping them. She runs upstairs. INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: WENDY’S ROOM - NIGHT 21 Billie and Ann are looking out the window at the car; Wendy rushes in and looks over their shoulders to see Sean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WENDY’S POV: Outside Sean’s house, ALLYSON, another senior, not as pretty, but very put together, sits in her convertible.  23 24 25 26 11/4/05 17. INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: WENDY’S ROOM - NIGHT 23

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Allyson? What does she want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a second later, they get their answer. Sean runs out of the house and gets in the car. INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: WENDY’S ROOM - NIGHT 25

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Apparently so.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (trying to remain aloof) That was fast.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: That poor boy. He has no idea what he’s getting himself into. The girls watch the car pull away, past a Brown Sedan that is gently rocking.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) That car has been there every night this week. A foot sticks out of the passenger window. The girls laugh. Billie goes back to the bed, but Wendy keeps looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Are we getting ready or what? INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: WENDY’S BATHROOM - NIGHT 26 Later that night, the three girls are in Wendy’s bathroom.  27 11/4/05 18. They have done their makeup and hair for a Saturday night, not too slutty, not too conservative. They look average, all-American, Midwestern. The girls look into the mirror into each other’s eyes smiling. N.E.R.D.’s song “Truth or Dare” starts playing. The SOUND OF A LOUD PARTY.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (yelling to be heard) They are complete magno-sluts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues. LOOKING AROUND THE ROOM, we see that everyone is treated to television sets running non-stop porn. Everyone drinks. Bong hits in the corner. In the background, girls disappear with guys into a variety of rooms. Basically, an average teen party. Sean stands with Allyson. RYAN (a girl, also a senior) is sitting on a kitchen counter nearby but out of earshot, with her boyfriend, AARON who is strumming a guitar. Alex, another senior, hands out beers to Sean and Allyson.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: I mean, I understand why the guys do it but the girls? It is total depravity. THE DOOR THAT SEAN IS LEANING ON OPENS, and a sexy girl comes out of the bedroom, wiping her mouth. Sean lets her pass, and she looks at him, smiling seductively. A moment later a guy comes out, buttoning his pants.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing) You should ask Ryan and Aaron. They got out.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Got out? What, it’s a cult?

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: (serious) I guess. I mean, I don’t know what else you would call it. Don’t you have to kill yourself to be in a cult?  11/4/05 19.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: And they all have sex with each other?

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: It’s pathetic, I know. Sean looks around at all the sex and drinking going on at this party.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: So, why is what you’re doing different than what they’re doing?

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: (defensive) It just is. See, we invite them every week and they never show. Obviously they think they’re better than us. Allyson notices something across the room.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god! They put in a pole? That is so cool. Allyson goes towards the stripper pole someone has installed in the rec room. ALLYSON (CONT’D) I wanna turn! Sean moves through the party, heading for the kitchen where he last saw Ryan. Two guys play Playstation in one room, while a girl gives another guy a lap dance, a blank stare on her face. Sean walks by TWO TANK-TOP GIRLS going to the bathroom wearing almost identical tank-tops.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you going to Brian’s thing tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah. I just wish it wasn’t a BJ party.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: Seriously. They should hand out bibs. Sean looks at Ryan.  28 11/4/05 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later on, Sean holds two beers as Ryan fixes her shoe, shaking a pebble out of it. She stumbles a little, then gets the shoe back on.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I’m not used to these. Aaron likes them.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Your boyfriend? She shrugs, as if to say, “what can you do”. SEAN (CONT’D) So you know Wendy?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Don’t. Really.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I just want to-- she’s my next door neighbor, you know?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. There’s a pause as Ryan and Sean watch a bunch of girls playing spin the bottle for a group of very rowdy guys. RYAN (CONT’D) Look, we just had an... arrangement, the eight of us. And when Aaron and I didn’t want to be with them anymore, we stopped. It’s not like I had to be de-programmed. Everyone wants it to be this big deal.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: So it’s more like a club?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What is it then? Ryan can’t really answer. The girls playing spin the bottle kiss and everyone cheers. SEAN (CONT’D) I can’t talk to her?  29 11/4/05 21.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: No. I mean, you might be able to talk to her, and maybe hang out at school. You should join Student Council. we’re, I mean they’re all on it. I’m not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. What, you figured we hung out and smoked crack?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: No. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Amnesty, and Model Congress and the Green Party. Last year we worked on two local campaigns. Sean looks shocked. RYAN (CONT’D) (kind of annoyed) Yeah, good students who have sex. It happens. They watch another group of girls kiss in the spin the bottle game and then get doused with beer. RYAN (CONT’D) I gotta find Aaron. She leaves Sean alone. He sees the SEXY GIRL WHO CAME OUT OF THE ROOM. She smiles at him and reaches out. He smiles shyly but lets her lead him back inside to a bedroom. As they enter, Tank-Top Girls look on.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: What is she going for, a world’s record? They laugh. INT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 29 In contrast to the party, Robert’s house is quiet, and serene. Marathon Man plays on the television. Our six are sitting on the floor of Robert’s sunken living room, despite the overstuffed and expensive furniture. They are all draped over each other, so that you can’t tell whose legs are whose.  11/4/05 22. During the scene they throw individually wrapped condoms at each other, winging them hard, like frisbees. In front of them are six SHOE BOXES, each one with a name on it, one for each of them.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I would definitely want to torture Jack Black.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: He’s funny!

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: He’s perfect torture material. He thinks he’s funny, so he’d be laughing. Until he cried. Why, who would you torture?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY BILLIE
dialogues.text: Lindsay Lohan. Lindsay Lohan. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Obvious and tired. Something original. Billie sticks out her tongue.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (to Ann, of the boxes) You putting in or taking out?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Taking out.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You always take out. I’m surprised that box isn’t empty.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: I’d torture Eminem. Without a doubt.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: He’s so smug, ya know. And he thinks he’s black. So I would tie him up and shock him with stuff. You know, feet in a tub of water. Ann reaches into her box and pulls out a small black marble.  11/4/05 23.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: The marble that I stole in fifth grade.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Because I’m going to give it back. Bad karma.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Like you know anything about karma. You should be worried about the yin and yang of that box.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Besides, I stole that marble. You just held onto it for me. Ann sticks her tongue out at Price.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You stole that marble because someone- -

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: -- Lisa Nishi--

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Right, Lisa Nishi, told you that you could sit with her if you did.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: I don’t remember that.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I do. She let you sit with her and her little fifth grade posse for one second because you only stole one marble.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Who the hell plays with marbles anyway? It’s so dipshitty 1957. Price shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’d torture at least one Olsen.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (clearly one of her faves)  11/4/05 24.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I would. She would be so spunky and then she'd break...it would be totally delicious. (to Ann) Why? wWho’d you torture?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I dunno. That Harry Potter kid probably.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Wendy? It’s your turn.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. In. Putting in.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Thank god. I’m sick of everyone taking stuff out. First you put it in the box and cry about whatever dumbass memory it stands for. And then you fish it out, saying you want it back.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Crying?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (picking up Price’s box) Yeah, and how many things are left in Senorita Price’s? Jonah fakes crying as he and Robert dip into the box.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Ohhh, this is the black nail polish I wore when I wanted to be Goth.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Screw you.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: I can do whatever I want. It’s my box.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes baby, it is.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What’s going in?  11/4/05 25. Wendy holds up her “Hoochie” necklace, that the freshmen pointed out earlier.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: That was a gift.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You’re always saying you don’t want us to apologize. Well, I don’t want us to bea joke. It’s not funny. Everyone thinks about that for a second.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: I’m funny.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You’re freaking hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: (still hung up on the game) You know the torturing? Well, what would we torture them for?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: To torture them.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Usually there’s a...end result. Like information or because you need to send a message to the other side. Robert starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The other side? There isn’t another side. We’re just saying -- if we were gonna break someone’s will, who would it be?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Um. I dunno. Do they have to be alive?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. You’re not gonna do it anyway, so no. Anyone.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Either Abraham Lincoln or me at twelve years old.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Fuck. That is such a good answer  11/4/05 26. Billie takes stock of the boxes. JONAH (CONT’D) (re. the boxes) I went. We all went. Robert stands up and stretches.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You guys gonna help clean up?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: You have a fucking maid.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Who reports back to my dad. Come on. Price, Jonah and Robert go out to start cleaning, Wendy and Ann start cleaning halfheartedly the area around them, what they can reach.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Price got really cute this summer. Billie lays back, her head in Ann’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: We have to stop using that word, “cute.” Bunnies are cute. Men are sexy.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: These aren’t men.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: They will be. She rolls over so she is looking at Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’11 be our men. Ten years from now they’1l be the strongest, smartest men anyone knows. And they’1l be ours.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: In ten years, I’m not gonna be here.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Why not? After all you invested? This is almost 17 years of training, of learning. You want to start from scratch?  11/4/05 27.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (upset) You’re kidding right? What, we’re gonna buy a big house in Utah?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) You’1l see. We’re all going to college together. And then get houses next door As if to prove her point, Billie grabs Price by the knees as he walks by; he falls on the floor. Then she straddles him. He tries to get up.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: (to Ann and Wendy) A little help, here? Instead the girls all sit on Price, and it turns into more of a wrestling match/tickling fight. Price is outnumbered so Robert and Jonah come to his “rescue.” Robert grabs Billie and Jonah grabs Wendy, leaving Ann on top of Price.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (teasing) Sorry, kids. It’s Saturday night and rules are rules. Without rules we would die.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (mocking her) That’s a little dramatic.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Billie is drama. Nonetheless they re-order, and not without some giggling. Now Robert is with Wendy, Price is with Billie, and Jonah is with Ann. The three couples start making out at various speeds, but each one is fully engaged with whomever they are with. As the camera pulls up and moves over the three couples they each end up on the floor, Robert on top of Wendy, he starts to take off his shirt; Billie straddles Price, his hands go underneath her pants; Ann holds Jonah’s hands down and slowly kisses him, moving down his chest Condoms litter the floor. We hold above them.  30 31 11/4/05 28. EXT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: ENTRANCE - NIGHT 30 Billie and Wendy sit on the front steps of Robert’s house. Wendy has her head in Billie’s lap, and they share a bottle of beer. Billie is looking at Wendy’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You have, like, sixteen split ends.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Shut up. They sit in silence, looking out on the suburban street everyone asleep, the gray hazy light of pre-dawn.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When we get to college--

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Shhh. This is the best time. This is the time I don’t think about things like college. Just-- Wendy gets it, and they return to the silence.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looking at her watch) It’s Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you’re a freaking genius. Shut up we’re supposed to be having quiet Zen time. Billie thwacks Wendy lightly, and the girls giggle, and return to silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in the beginning, the video of girls, this time just after a football game outside a local Denny’s. This GIRL looks down the whole time, she’s distracted as she text messages someone.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: Why should guys have all the fun? TI mean, if I have to lay there anyway, at least I could be having fun, right?  32 33 11/4/05 29. She gets distracted by her text messages, and wanders away. TEEN GIRL #6 walks up and fixes her hair, then fishes a condom out of her back pocket

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: I’m like a boyscout --

dialogues.speaker: YELLING GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: (she flips them off) I’m prepared. I don’t wanna have to have a baby at the prom. That’s just ghetto. She looks at the condom, and then puts it back in her pocket. She smiles, knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bergman & Mayer homes seen from overhead. It’s Monday morning, German-engineered cars are being driven to various workplaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy comes into the kitchen. Wearing low-slung jeans and a sweater, she looks relatively tame. Wendy grabs some orange juice. ABBY BERGMAN (40’s, dresses mostly in caftans and wears a lot of ethnic jewelry) drinks coffee.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I would kill for your body. Wendy kisses her mom on the cheek

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The best thing I can tell you is don’t get pregnant. I’d have a flat stomach today if I had stayed a person and not become a mom.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Mommm.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: See? Nathan comes into the kitchen in his baggy jeans and long T-shirt, he’s half asleep.  34 11/4/05 30.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (opening the refrigerator) Nobody ate the coffee cake I made?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can’t eat that stuff. Abby doesn’t say anything. Nathan takes a piece for himself, eats it quickly and washes it down with milk from the container.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now can we go?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I gotta get my bag. Nathan leaves Abby and Wendy alone for a moment. A pause. ensemble.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You ready for your college interviews?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You worried I won’t clean up okay? That I’1l embarrass you?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (cowed) It’s just a question. Wendy reaches over and fingers her mother’s

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (earnest) Mom, honestly. You could do so much better. Nathan and Wendy leave, Abby sits alone in the kitchen for a moment, her shoulders sagging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Nathan get into Wendy’s car; she sits for a moment, staring at the Mayer house.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (mocking Wendy a little) Can we go?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hold on.  35 11/4/05 31. Wendy gets half out of the car and then sits down again. WENDY (CONT’D) You go.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Ask him if he needs a ride.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Shut up. He’1l think I’m gay.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I’m not gay.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So then what do you care?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I care. I completely care.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Are you going to ask any girls out today?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So why not be a little gay? For me.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (lamest comeback ever) You be a little gay. Wendy reaches over and opens the passenger door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan rings the bell and waits, backing up a little. From the side of the house, a stream of water, followed by HELEN MAYER, 40, sexy even in her sweats, she holds the garden hose in front of her, watering everything she sees, turning most of it to mud.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (giving a little wave) So I guess you’re our new neighbors.  36 37 11/4/05 32. Nathan is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (whispers) Yeah. Uhh. I’m your next-door Nathan. Helen puts down the hose and walks over, her hand extended. Nathan shakes it, staring at his hand touching hers.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Your next-door neighbor, Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Helen.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Nathan backs up and heads back to the car. INT. WENDY’S CAR - MORNING 36

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I forgot. She stopped me, and... He’s dejected. Wendy rolls her eyes, goes out to Helen as Nathan watches.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hi. My brother was supposed to ask you if Sean needed a ride. To school.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I think he was dropped on his head a lot. My brother. Not your son. Helen laughs.  11/4/05 33.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: That'd be great. The ride. Not the head dropping. Helen goes back to the hose and sprays an upstairs window. BILL MAYER, (movie star handsome with 10 extra pounds) opens it after a second.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (out the window) You rang?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Sorry, I thought that was Sean’s room. Tell him he has a ride waiting. (to Wendy) We have to get him acar. Actually we have to get me a car, too. We’re city people, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It’s not a problem. An awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Sean said you’re a scientist?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Trying to be. I’m ina bit of a holding pattern. But yes. Are you interested in-- Before she can answer, Sean runs out of the house and smiles at Wendy. HELEN (CONT’D) (to Sean) Have fun. Sean gives her a wave; he and Wendy walk towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Nothing. You nervous?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Well, now I am.  38 11/4/05 34. They get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls into the school parking lot. Nathan gets out of the car and heads inside but Sean doesn’t move. Wendy is about to say something when she sees Robert and Jonah pulling up and she panics.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (cold) Okay kid. Your taxi ride is over.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Unless you plan on paying me. The ride is over.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Oh. (embarrassed) Oh, yeah. (he gets his stuff, fumbles) Sorry. Wendy feels terrible but there is nothing she can do, so she lets Sean leave. SEAN (CONT’D) Sorry. Wendy doesn’t say anything. WENDY’s POV: she watches Sean go into school in the rearview mirror, and she sees Robert and Jonah walk by, completely oblivious to the fact that Sean was in her car a few moments ago. Wendy loses sight of Robert and Jonah until there is a loud bang on the roof of her car. Wendy throws the door open.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Dammit! Robert puts his face on the passenger window blowing fishy faces.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re a jackass.  39 11/4/05 35. Robert grabs his crotch and Wendy laughs. She gets out of the car, Robert and Jonah hug her hello.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Your friend didn’t say hi.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He was in a hurry, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Your new neighbor? Wendy is about to answer when Price comes out of the school and runs up to them.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) We need you. Wendy follows him into the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy, Price and Robert find Billie eating a big bag of Doritos. Billie sits opposite Ryan and Aaron in the lounge, a wordless face-off. A small crowd is gathering, though they try to be casual. Ryan isn’t saying anything, she’s trying to focus on Aaron. And she looks like she might cry.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (to Ryan) Doritos?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: we’re leaving?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Senior class meeting? And then some other thing.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (nonchalant ) Okay. We can go to a “thing”.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Actually, “some other thing”.  11/4/05 36.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: That too. Billie finally looks away from Ryan and smiles her Cheshire Cat Grin. Wendy pulls her away.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Don’t be an instigator.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (loud enough for Ryan to hear) I’m just making sure our little housewife is being a good girl. Wendy looks back at Ryan, who is clearly upset by the almost -confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do I always say to you?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (playing along) It’s because they named her Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: After a soap opera. Don’t name children after soap operas. How many times do I have to tell you people? Wendy and Billie laugh. Price and Robert come back up to the two of them, now that the moment has passed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) Did you have to wrestle her? Was it really ugly?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: She didn’t have to do anything. I’m as harmless as a kitten. Robert nuzzles Billie’s neck while “meowing into it,” Price takes Wendy’s hand and kisses it gently. They find Ann and Jonah waiting for them and walk outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill is lying in bed, eyes open, not sleeping but not getting up, he’s in his work clothes. We hear the sound of peeing, and then Helen comes to the bathroom sink  11/4/05 37.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Sean’s at school?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That girl came over for him?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Wendy. I liked her. Funny. Helen watches Bill, who rolls over and faces her Neither says anything as she holds a pregnancy test strip in her hands. She looks down and then looks at him. Her look says it all.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Unless by “error proof test” they mean full of errors, take three tests and all three will be wrong. She sits on the bed next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What do we do? Helen looks at him, touched.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Thanks for that.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: The “we.” Thanks for the “we.”

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It’s always “we,” dummy. Bill takes Helen in his arms and holds her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I can’t wait another eighteen years. Waiting three weeks feels like a death sentence. She looks at Bill.  11/4/05 38. HELEN (CONT’D) Bad choice of words. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What are you sorry for? Helen shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It’s a constant war. (he doesn’t understand) I can’t be bossed around by an internal organ. She turns and looks at him. HELEN (CONT’D) Is that alright? Bill kisses her, and nods. HELEN (CONT’D) You’re going to be late.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You’re right. She watches him leave, he dashes back in and gives her a quick peck on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tonight? wWe’1ll talk. Helen nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie is sitting by herself waiting for Ann and Wendy. The two Tank-Top Girls sit nearby.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: His name is Sam.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: Sean. His name is Sean.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: He was cute.  42 11/4/05 39.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: I don’t remember. But he was... (indicates size) I mean seriously! The girls laugh. Billie looks over at them, all smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: (trying to be cool) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I like how you two dress alike. I was thinking of getting some working girls for my brother’s bachelor party and you two could be like a twin act. They’d love it. You guys are what, ten bucks an hour? Or do you just take food stamps? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: TANK-TOP GIRL
dialogues.text: (whispers it) Bitch. Tank-Top Girl #1 pulls Tank-Top Girl #2 away.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Alright fine! I’11 pay in crack. God hookers are so picky these days. The girls are gone, and Billie smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean sits in a bay -- the students, including Wendy and Jonah are seated around large tables arranged in a circle. As a STUDENT speaks, Wendy scrunches down in her chair and watches Sean carefully, over the top of her book.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: I think what Aristotle is saying is that man, well people, you know, like man and woman, well they’re in a battle that can’t be won. But they have to fight, cause, you know, they have this nature this whaddya call it? Nature? Likea Sicilian.  43 11/4/05 40. There’s a pause as the class digests this insight. Wendy raises her eyes to Sean, seeing what he’1ll do -- Sean raises his hand. The PHILOSOPHY TEACHER gestures at him to lower his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOSOPHY TEACHER
dialogues.text: I’m just the guide, I’m not the boss. Sean doesn’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOSOPHY TEACHER
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sean, condescending) You can participate.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I think you mean Sisyphus. Sisyphian.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOSOPHY TEACHER
dialogues.text: (annoyed) We don’t correct. We add and we contribute. But everything said at the table has merit. (pointedly) Do you have something to contribute? Sean looks down. Wendy smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It’s Promethean.

dialogues.speaker: PHILOSOPHY TEACHER
dialogues.text: Wendy?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to Sean) If you’re going to help him out, you might as well really help him out. (to the class) Promethean. Not Sisyphian. (a pause) Not everything said here has merit. The Teacher doesn’t know what to say. Wendy smiles at Sean. Then she looks at Jonah, who hasn’t glanced up from the book he is reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert finds a seat in the classroom. Allyson suddenly leans over him, her hair and her breasts very much in his personal space.  44 11/4/05 41.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: Hey, Robert.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you Rob? Or Robbie?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Dunno.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: So this Saturday we’re having a party. To celebrate...well I guess, the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’m busy.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. But you could come, right? I mean, if you wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sure. But I don’t want to. Allyson flips her hair and makes sure Robert can see all the way down her shirt.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: You sure? Cause we have killer parties. Robert opens his book, not responding right away.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Allyson, I wasn’t interested last year. I’m not interested this year. And no amount of your cleavage is gonna change my mind. She stands up straight and harrumphs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan watches Helen change. He looks down and sees that there is no car in the driveway.  45 46 11/4/05 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Off The Wall’ by Michael Jackson blares. Helen dances around. The front doorbell rings. Helen answers it: it is Nathan with comic books.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Is Sean here?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Track practice, I think.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh. (a long pause) He lent me these. There’s a pause as Helen waits for him to say something more. NATHAN (CONT’D) You need any help unpacking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael Jackson is still singing. Nathan is cooking at the stove, Helen is unpacking boxes as Nathan cooks, keeping one eye on the strange young man.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Do you have a strainer?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I’m sure we do-- I just can’t find it. Nathan keeps cooking.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (about the music) Is this Michael Jackson?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: God, you weren’t even born when this came out...  11/4/05 43.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (bristles) I knew it was Michael Jackson. There’s a pause. NATHAN (CONT’D) So, do you get to stay home all day?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You mean, like a housewife? God no. I work for a drug company. Research and Development. I used to teach but now that Sean is old enough, I get to have a real job.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: You didn’t go to work today?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I took a couple of weeks to get settled. But there doesn’t seem to be that much to do. Another awkward pause, that Nathan struggles to fill.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: What does your, I mean Sean’s father, you know...

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Bill? He’s in finance. Banking. The funny thing is that he is terrible with money unless it is in the millions. That isn’t funny at all, is it?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: No, I guess not. They smile at each other. He pours the chocolate sauce onto the cake, let’s it harden and then starts to garnish. It is a beautiful pastry.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You know him as the decaying King of Pop. A pervert with an alien face. I think this is the last of the pure Michael Jackson. The song ends, and “She’s Out Of My Life” starts. HELEN (CONT’D) Bill loves this song.  47 11/4/05 44. Nathan smirks, but hides it as he turns to serve the cake. HELEN (CONT’D) (looking at the cake) Jesus. You made that from my cupboard?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: It would be better if you had fresh hazelnut. And powdered sugar. But it’s still really good. Helen is eating, Nathan doesn’t try it.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You cook a lot?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: At home. At first I could only make steak, rice and green beans. Not that my mom or sister even notice. But I taught myself a lot of stuff. Pastries, and fresh bread, those are easy. I’m working on a glazed salmon with risotto. Did you know you have to drive 90 minutes to get frisee lettuce? Helen tries not to choke with laughter but Nathan doesn’t see her, since he is still cooking.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I’d love to try anything you make.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (already formulating a plan) Really? Helen smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Nathan smiles to himself. INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: WENDY’S ROOM - NIGHT 47 Wendy, Billie and Ann are doing homework  48 11/4/05 45.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) It takes me twice as long to do your English paper as it does for you to do my physics homework. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (teasing) Cause words is hard.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: And we’re stupid.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I thought Asian people loved physics.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Who’s Asian? I’m full-blooded Scandinavian. This cracks the girls up.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (looks at the clock) Shit. I gotta go. (to Wendy) You’1l drive me? Wendy rolls her eyes and Billie spanks her playfully. INT. WENDY’S CAR: DRIVING - NIGHT 48 Wendy drives Billie home, Billie is still working on her homework in the passenger seat

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: How many schools do we have in common?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: For next year? I don’t know, five maybe.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Out of?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Six or seven.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Those are good odds, then. That we’1l all be in school together.  49 50 11/4/05 46.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jonah’1l get in wherever he wants. But he’1l go where we go.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Why? The car cruises by the Brown Sedan, rocking, fogged up windows.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: If a guy can’t find a bed for you, then he shouldn’t be allowed to get any.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Agreed. Wendy watches the car out her back window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean is working on a drawing when his pen fades. Sean shakes it to get more ink. It fades again and then runs out. Sean starts looking through the books and clothes. He picks up a book, throws it in the corner. There is a thud and then a second lighter thud. Sean's confused. He picks up another book, does it again. A thud, and then another thud, softer. Sean picks up a book, and doesn't throw it down. A small, soft thud. Sean looks around, another thud, coming from the window. He opens the window shade. Wendy is outside, slowly dribbling the basketball purposefully in his backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy tries to make a shot, and misses.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And you were hoping for a basketball scholarship.  11/4/05 47. Wendy ignores him. She retrieves the basketball and makes the shot. Sean sits on the ground. Wendy plays for a few more moments. Sean waits her out hoping that she'll speak. She keeps playing, but finally talks.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It’s not possible. To be with me. Really. She holds the ball.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (suddenly nervous) You do want to be with me, right? Sean steals the ball and then dribbles slowly, trying to get the slowest dribble possible, concentrating to control his frustration.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I want to kiss you. Pretty much every time I see you I want to kiss you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That girl, Ryan? She was one of my best friends. And now I don’t talk to her ever.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: And Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, yeah. I mean, I saw him naked a whole lot. But that’s different. I mean, he could just be an ex-boyfriend, right? You have ex-girlfriends, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know if that’s the same.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know you don’t. You don’t really know anything about me, do you? Wendy steals the ball back, dribbles, does a lay-up and misses.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It doesn't make sense.  11/4/05 48.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (re. missed basket) You mean, since I'm so naturally athletic? (Sean rolls his eyes, Wendy dribbles again, not looking at him) You haven’t even asked if it is true.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Well is it? Sean rolls his eyes, Wendy dribbles again, not looking at him. SEAN (CONT’D) It's a Greek tragedy waiting to happen. Wendy wings the ball at him, hard.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don’t live in that world--

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: --What? You don’t live in what? The world of boyfriends? Of first dates? Of holding hands?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No. You, jackass. Of disposable girlfriends. Of blowjobs for bracelets. Of macking and hooking up and going down and text-messaging some asshole who will cum all over my shirt. That world. Sean retrieves the ball, and starts his slow meticulous dribble.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) You don’t know what you’re missing.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I have a pretty good idea.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What about the other world. Of boyfriends, and one girl, and one guy, and you know, we just go out. With each other. Nobody else.  11/4/05 49.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Ahh yes. Fairytale land. The land of make believe.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What if it was real? Wendy marches up to Sean and kisses him hard, mostly to stop him from talking.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) You’re going to rescue me? You and me against the world?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (earnest ) If you want me to. They kiss again. This time it is passionate and real, and Sean sighs, despite trying to be cool and manly.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (teasing him) What was that?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Did you just sigh?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: No. I made a noise. People make noises.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You sighed. Like a girl in a romance novel.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I just made a noise. Sean starts to walk back to his house. Wendy lets out a huge sigh. Sean starts to laugh. Sean lets out a louder sigh. Wendy reciprocates. Sean lets out a little moan. Wendy does the same. A loud moan, and Wendy does it louder. Wendy howls. Sean bays.  51 52 53 11/4/05 50. A dog, somewhere nearby, howls back. They crack up. The moment is real and intimate for Wendy and she pulls away. SEAN (CONT’D) Just leave them. Be with me.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Say maybe.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe what? She kisses him once more and then runs inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This parking lot is outside an all ages dance club. THE EIGHTH TEEN GIRL teeters on too high heels.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: (in the middle of a statement) --so TV is totally giving you all these messages about your booty. And mine is so...white. I don’t want a white-- EXT. PRICE’S HOUSE: FRONT DOOR - EVENING 52 Wendy knocks on the front door of Price’s large house which is a little shabbier than everyone else’s. INT. PRICE’S HOUSE: BEDROOM - EVENING 53 Wendy knocks on the door of Price’s bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Price?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank god. One second. Wendy sits on Price’s bed, flipping through the Magazines. She notices that on some pages there is writing.  11/4/05 51. On one page it says “I’m four inches taller” above a picture of a famous actor. On another page it says, “Get those Abs”. Wendy puts the magazine down. The bathroom door opens but Price doesn’t come out.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: You’re going to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m not. Price comes out of the bathroom. He has dyed his formerly surfer blond hair black and possibly gotten extensions so that he has a forelock of hair in front of his eyes. He has one a smallish vintage t-shirt and cords instead of his normal clothes (which weren’t so super trendy). He looks like an Emo boy from a Bright Eyes concert.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your hair.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: I showed him some pictures. This guy in Cleveland. And he was really cool. He had tattoos on his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I just --

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Is it really bad? Price looks in the mirror, pulls the lock of hair over his eyes and pouts. PRICE (CONT’D) It’s nice. (he looks at Wendy) You think people will notice.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: It would be worse if they didn’t.  11/4/05 52.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Being ignored is not the high school revenge you think it is. She comes up behind Price and hugs him from behind. He turns around and they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: (still hugging her) I heard you thought I got hotter over the summer . Wendy moves away a tiny bit.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I think I said cuter.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: There’s a difference?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (looking at him) You did. You lost weight or got in shape or something.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: I got a nose job.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Yeah. And I do crunches every day. A hundred, sometimes five hundred. I lay in bed at night and if I do some of them half-assed, I get out and do them again.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. You got a nose job? Price just smiles at her, and goes back to the mirror. Wendy stands on tiptoes and looks at his face carefully, coming kissing close, then kisses Price on the lips. He pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: It isn’t night yet.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Last year, Billie made some comment  54 55 11/4/05 53.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (shocked) About your nose? Nice.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: I just wanted to look good for you guys. It’s worth it to me. To have all of you, each of you. I’d get ten more surgeries and do a thousand more sit-ups for you. Wouldn’t you? For all of us? His passion is frightening. She backs up a little.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You wanna walk over to Robert’s with me?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Yeah. In a minute. Wendy watches him look in the mirror again. INT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 54 Robert sleeps with Ann. Price, his hair still black, is with Wendy. Billie is with Jonah. Wendy touches Price’s hair and pulls her hand away. She looks into his eyes, but he won’t look at her. She pushes Price away, and he doesn’t pursue her. After a minute Price stands up and walks to another room where we hear a TV turn on. Wendy stands up and goes outside. EXT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: FRONT DOOR - NIGHT 55 Wendy and Billie get comfortable on the steps, this time Billie wrapping her arms around Wendy, who sits a step below her.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Beer? Billie passes it to her.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I just didn’t have any-- I didn’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Listen, don’t ever fake it. Right?  56 11/4/05 54.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Cause faking it is for dumbass girls who hook-up with the first guy in baggy jeans and a earth-fucking SUV.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: We are not those girls. You are not that girl.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. There’s a pause.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What kind of girl am I?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You’re...ummmm. You’re (she can’t say whatever it is she wants to say, so she makes a joke) A Very Bad Girl.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Seriously... What kind? Billie takes a lock of Wendy’s hair and makes a curl on her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: ...and When she was good she was very very good and when she was bad she was horrid. Billie leaves her hand on Wendy’s face. Then Wendy leans on Billie’s knee and holds on. INT. MAYER HOUSE: SEAN’S ROOM - NIGHT 56 Sean is sound asleep in his bed when the window opens. Wendy pulls herself in, falling and making a loud thud. Sean wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Are you lost?  57 11/4/05 55. Wendy takes his hand and slowly puts it to her face. SEAN (CONT’D) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (softly) I don’t know what I’m doing here. Sean kisses her and Wendy immediately goes for his pants. He takes her hands, kisses each finger and then stops there.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (gently) Go to sleep. Sean buries his face in her hair, and Wendy closes her eyes as they spoon. SEAN (CONT’D) Just so you know, I may jump you in the middle of the night. Wendy giggles.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Good. She drifts off to sleep. INT. MAYER HOUSE: SEAN’S ROOM - NIGHT 57 Sean and Wendy are naked, their bodies close, their eyes open, looking at each other. Wendy looks away for a second and Sean immediately gets her gaze back. Sean is careful but passionate and Wendy is taking it all in. Her gaze wanders again.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What are you looking at? Wendy looks back at Sean -- caught.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Nothing. We’re all alone. Wendy can see that Sean doesn’t understand. She buries her face in his shoulder.  58 59 11/4/05 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun rises over the two houses. INT. MAYER HOUSE: SEAN’S ROOM - DAWN 59 Bill, dressed for work stands in the doorway of Sean’s room.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Whatcha doing?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (whispers) Whatcha doing?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I wanted to see Sean before I went to work. Inside Sean’s room we see Wendy is hiding next to the bed. Bill looks at Helen, a little mournful. INTERCUT WENDY LISTENING TO BILL/HELEN.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I didn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I saw it. The “Good Night Moon” look.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: That look you used to get when you would be reading to Sean. That “I’m a dad” look.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I can’t help it.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You’re already a dad.  11/4/05 57.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m not arguing.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I start next week. And we’ve paid off all our credit card bills. All of them. And the car?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yeah -- so that makes it okay, a BMW?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: A Beemer. Which you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Please stop saying that.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (teasing him) A blue beemer. Bill sighs. HELEN (CONT’D) I don’t want to be Mommy for another seventeen years.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That’s fine. Just don’t say we’re trading a BMw for a baby.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It’s just, if things were different--

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: --hey, I said I was sorry. Bill says nothing. Helen heads back to their bedroom. HELEN (CONT’D) I’m going back to bed. Bill watches her, then grabs his briefcase.  60 61 11/4/05 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is between classes, students chat in the hallways girls hold hands with other girls, guys wrestle each other. It all seems chaotic, but no more so than any other school. Wendy is near the lounge area when Sean jogs up and starts walking next to her

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Don’t.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I’m walking next to you. Wendy walks faster. Sean walks with her.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Stop it. Wendy pulls Sean into a nearby storage closet, unaware that across the hall BILLIE SEES HER GO IN THERE WITH SEAN. Billie stops, Ann doesn’t notice that she has stopped and keeps walking -- Billie isn’t confused. She’s angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean tries to kiss her, but Wendy stops him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You can’t and then you can. You won’t and then you do. How much more of this am I supposed to stick around for?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Until graduation? Sean lets this sink in, then he starts to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Now you want me? Wendy kisses him, trying to convince him.  62 11/4/05 59.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Come on. Seven months. You can’t wait for me?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: If you were in the army or something, yeah, I could wait for you. You’re going to hook-up with three guys for seven months. So no, I don’t think so. Wendy takes his hand and puts it on her breast.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You want what your parents have, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I guess. They seem pretty happy.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I guess. Wendy doesn’t respond right away.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Meet me this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (trying not to give in) I don’t know. She runs his hand over her breast.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe. Wendy kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Wait in here. Wendy opens the door and closes Sean in; Sean stands in the dark closet, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Wendy gets into the room she sees Billie and Ann and sits between them.  11/4/05 60. Billie reaches out and grabs the skin on Wendy’s elbow. It doesn’t really hurt, but it quietly gets Wendy’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You have something you want to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (playing it off) I stole some french fries from you yesterday at lunch. Billie pulls, harder and is about to retort when:

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: (in her bitchiest tone) What’s wrong girls? Did someone forget to feed the lesbian? A gay girl with a buzz cut and another gay girl with tattoos on her neck laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, even the lesbians don’t want you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: They were laughing at you, Allyson. You need to learn how it works, Al. That little man in the canoe down there won’t help himself, you know. At least the guys I sleep with know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: You’re like completely perverted.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Jesus. You give new meaning to the word “meaningless sex” you know? I don’t mean the act. I mean the gender. Without meaning.

dialogues.speaker: ALLYSON
dialogues.text: (barely able to breathe) And yet, you’re the ones who are still skanks. The SCIENCE TEACHER has walked in.

dialogues.speaker: SCIENCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: Excuse me?  11/4/05 61.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I believe Allyson just referred to us as skanks. At least that’s what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: SCIENCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: Allyson? The teacher leaves it at that and then starts writing on the board, back turned. Allyson flips off the girls. Billie, Wendy and Ann all put their fingers up to their mouths in a V shape and stick out their tongues. SCIENCE TEACHER (CONT’D) (without turning around) Is there a problem girls?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Women. We want to be referred to as women. The teacher turns around but the girls are sitting, quietly. Ann winks at Allyson.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers to Wendy) I better not have seen what I just saw. Did I see that?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No. Billie grabs Wendy’s arm a little to hard, a moment that is part violent, part desperate.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: We’1l die without you. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I have to go to the bathroom. (trying a joke) You can live without me for a minute, right? Wendy slips from Billie’s grasp and walks out of the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (real worry) What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it.  63 11/4/05 62. Billie gives Allyson a last glare and then looks down, contemplating her plan. INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: WENDY’S ROOM - DAY 63 Wendy and Sean are kissing, half undressed. Wendy moves toward Sean but misjudges the distance on the narrow bed and starts to slip off. Sean tries to grab at her, but she falls. Wendy is laughing hysterically. Sean goes to help her up and she pulls him off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You didn’t land on your butt

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It was just my head. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t that bad. She reaches over and slaps Sean on the ass.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Shut up, that didn’t hurt.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Your rings?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It’s okay. She hits him again. He slaps her lightly back.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No. Hit me for real.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hit me for real. I want to feel what it’s like to be spanked for real.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna hit you. Wendy gets on the bed, Sean follows, dubious.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m telling you it’s okay. You’re not gonna hurt me if I tell you it’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (he is upset at the idea) No.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Nobody ever spanked me. Not once.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
