dialogues.text: I got spanked for stealing once. It hurt a lot. And it’s cruel. I’m never spanking my kids.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (half playing) You have to. Sometimes they’re bad and they have to learn. I never learned. Hit me. Sean won’t do it so Wendy hits him on the arm. And then the leg. She smacks his face. Sean does nothing. Then he pounces on her, turns her over and spanks her He stops.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: This is really weird.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Do it again. wWhy’d you stop?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Cause I think this is... (searches for word) ...abnormal. Wendy gets up.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (pissed off) I’m not abnormal.  11/4/05 64.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t say you were. I said that this was just...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No fine, I’m totally abnormal and you just want the girl next door.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You are the girl next door.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Come back. Wendy sits on the side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I have Calculus to do.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: So do I.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So get to work.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Don’t you want me to take you out on dates?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t you have done that before we had sex? (Sean doesn’t laugh) I don’t know how to be a girlfriend. I’m not sure I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Come here. Wendy doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: World fucking peace.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hey look, it’s Sarcastic Man. Able to be a jerk in a single bound.  11/4/05 65.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Bite me. She does. He laughs. Sean flips Wendy over and spanks her lightly, once.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It doesn’t feel like much. Sean hits her again, testing his strength.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You guys never did this before? On your Saturday nights?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Are we talking or spanking? Sean hits Wendy hard, harder than he has before.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. Ow. Everyone has to be into it. We all have to agree and some people don’t like to get spanked, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Do you? He hits her again. She reaches back and hits him. SEAN (CONT’D) You can’t hit me.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We have rules now?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (getting nasty) I thought you’d like it if we had rules. Don’t you guys have rules in your club.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Don’t call it a club!

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What else would you call it?  11/4/05 66.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We’re friends. We’ve known each other since we were in elementary school. I love them. Sean smacks her, three times. Wendy finally loses her temper and pulls herself up and away from him.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (shrugging) It’s your game. Wendy thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You make it sound perverted. Calling it a club.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You don’t think it’s perverted? Sean looks at her, still pouting a little.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I never worry. Like about if I’m pretty, or sexy. I never worry about parties or being alone -- cause we love each other. And I know you think it’s weird, or whorish. But my friends are cool people.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Who you like to fuck.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So? I like sleeping with you too. And you’re never gonna make me feel like they do. A pause and then Sean moves towards her, but she backs away .

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Are those the only rules?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Be honest. That’s the only other one.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (softening) I guess you’re breaking that one with me?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.  11/4/05 67. Wendy looks in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Were you lying?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: When you said you loved me?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I never said that.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: But you do. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Say it then.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. She hits him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Say it back!

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe. A pause as she looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You don’t have to--

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We kiss now, right? They move to kiss.  64 65 66 11/4/05 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This parking lot is in front of a large house, where the house party rages inside.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: (sitting on a car) There’s two types of lesbians. Girls who actually wanna do it with other girls, and girls who just wanna make guys go crazy.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: (standing nearby, smirking) Or, not popular, and popular.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: It’s stupid. Like I have to kiss a girl to get a guy. What moron thought that up? Her boyfriend comes up and scoops her into his arms, kissing her and carrying her away. She waves a sweet “bye-bye” to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen sits on the front stairs with a cordless phone calling someone. She gets no answer, then she chucks the phone into the bushes. It makes a beep, and she scrambles after it.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Hello? Nothing. She throws the phone back on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy’s car pulls into the driveway. Nathan notices Helen is sleeping on the front steps, the phone in her hands. Wendy looks as well. Nathan opens the door

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I’1l be right back.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Don’t. It’s not our business.  67 11/4/05 69.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: What if she’s hurt? Wendy has no answer to that, so she lets Nathan go to the house then after a beat she follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Nathan slowly approach the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Ummm. There is a small twitch from Helen, so he tries again. NATHAN (CONT’D) Ummmm. Hi. Helen opens her eyes, looking at Nathan; her hair is stuck to the side of her face. Nathan is, as always overwhelmed by her beauty. Wendy is more shocked.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Oh. God this must seem... I mean, you must think--

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: You’re locked out, huh?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Not exactly. Bill’s late and I don’t have a car. I have somewhere to be. Nathan takes a step back. But Wendy stays still, something about Helen makes her want to stay and help.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Do you need a ride?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It’s fine. I can call a taxi or something.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No. That’s crazy. Seriously, we want to take you. Nathan nods.  11/4/05 70. 68 INT. WENDY’S CAR: DRIVING - DAY 68 Helen sits in the front seat while Wendy drives; everyone is quiet for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: My mom’s prom date never showed.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (mean) That’s not the same thing. (after a beat) Actually it’s exactly the same thing. That jackass. We might as well be in high school. (suddenly yelling)

dialogues.speaker: DAMMIT
dialogues.text: (and then back to “normal”) We should go back. You shouldn’t be driving me places. This is completely through the looking glass.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You want to go back?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: If by back you mean Chicago, then yes. I wanna go back. (pause) No. Keep going. It’s on Duane. About three blocks away I guess.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh. Helen wonders what Wendy knows about what is on Duane.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (suddenly very much a mother) It’s not...you shouldn’t worry about me, okay? I’m fine. Okay? (glances at Nathan) And you can’t come in. (she sits back) Sean says you want to be a scientist.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess I do. Maybe a physicist or something in engineering. It’s not exactly something they teach at school.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I took Chemistry in college because Bill, Sean’s dad, was in it. And I just was so smitten with him. And then when it turned out I was better at it -- more gifted I guess -- he was incredibly sweet about it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m just in the regular classes.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: This summer, maybe we can find you an internship or something. 1I’11 look into it for you. It’1ll be good for college some practical education. EXT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE - DAY 69 The car pulls to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I remember this place. We got our vaccinations near here.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We’1l wait. Helen looks at Wendy in a quick thank you and then gets out of the car; Wendy turns the car around and parks then looks at the entrance to the doctor’s office and sighs deeply.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Nothing. It just sucks, watching someone be alone. Nathan looks at Wendy and then there’s a long pause as they both sit in the car. They both stretch out their legs, so they are facing each other, Nathan in back Wendy in front.  11/4/05 72.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I think I might have farted in gym yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (trying not to laugh) Okay. You think so?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Well we were running laps. And there was a noise. And I think it was my shoes. But then Andy says, “Whew, stop with the beans, Bergman.” And then nobody would run behind me. And running is the only thing I can do in gym other than wrestle. But it probably wasn’t me -- I mean gym is pretty smelly already, you know?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He’s a jackass. His brother is a jackass and his father is a huge ass. He has a genetic predisposition to asshole. Nathan smiles a thank you to Wendy and then there is another long silence.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (picking up Wendy’s comment from before) But when do you see people when they aren’t alone?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Before, you said it sucked watching someone be alone. Like you never see that. When do you watch people and they aren’t alone?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Are you serious? All the time. People are always around other people. wWe’re social, you know, as animals.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Like right now, we’re together, and not alone.  11/4/05 73.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (dubious) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You’re here with me, right? I mean, you’re not a figment of my imagination are you?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So I’m not alone, and you’re not alone.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s what it means.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Alone. I don’t think that’s the definition of alone. Wendy looks at Nathan and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You are so weird.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (proudly) I know. Wendy smiles at him and then resumes looking out the window at the building. Nathan starts to say something to Wendy. NATHAN (CONT’D) I go to school with you, you know.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (not looking at him) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: So I know-- Wendy sits up.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Don’t. Okay?  70 11/4/05 74. INT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 70 The couples are now Wendy and Jonah, Robert and Billie, and Ann and Price. All three guys are sitting, shirts off. The girls are in shirts and underwear, the guys are in boxers. The six boxes are stacked nearby, closed. Billie watches Wendy closely as each couple is making out. Wendy is trying to focus on Jonah but she feels awkward, she keeps sitting, pulling her hair off her face. Jonah is trying to keep in the moment, but something is off, he knows it. She puts her hand down on him and then pulls it away. She sits up, then re-settles.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: She won’t do it, will she? Everyone stops. Wendy stands up but doesn’t leave.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You thinking of running away? Maybe we should try that whole fantasy thing Jonah was talking about. Hold you down, make you scream.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Shut up, Billie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You have no idea what it means if she leaves right now.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (confused) It doesn’t mean anything. (to Wendy) Right? Wendy can’t speak.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: (to Billie) We’re fine. Stop being such a brat. Now Ann sits up and pulls away from Price. Everything is breaking down.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: You can’t force her. That’s a rule.  11/4/05 75.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) We can stop if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Yeah, we can stop.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: We can’t fucking stop. Billie stands up.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We don’t stop, we don’t turn back

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (to Billie) Hey, psycho, let me know when Billie returns.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Billie advances on Wendy, she isn’t wearing her underwear and that seems to make her bolder.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at me. Look at you. We’re seventeen. We’ll never look like this again. Our bodies want it, we want it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don’t want it. Billie storms over to Wendy and hits her hard with a closed fist. Suddenly the guys are pulling them apart, not before Wendy hits back, just as viciously.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You bitch.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Original. The guys keep them separated but Billie is still fighting.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: (trying for a joke) Break out the mud. Or the jello. Nobody laughs.  11/4/05 76.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You either do Jonah right now, or you are so completely gone.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I “do” him? We don’t “do” each other. Billie breaks free and grabs Wendy by the back of the neck and forces her towards Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I’m not kidding you. Jonah backs away and Robert grabs Billie, giving Wendy a chance to break free.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Let’s just stop. We’1ll have some food. Or watch a DVD.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Shut up Ann.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Billie!

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You all shut up. Wendy breaks free and moves towards Billie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gonna go home and cry to your boyfriend about how you almost cheated on him?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: What’s she talking about? The guys and Ann look at Wendy.  71 72 11/4/05 77.

dialogues.speaker: ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wendy?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: She’s cheating on us? There’s a beat as Wendy doesn’t say anything. She isn’t denying it and one by one the group gets it -- she is cheating on them. EXT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: FRONT DOOR - NIGHT 71 Wendy stumbles out of the house, crying. As the door shuts we see Billie standing, Ann behind her, the guys behind Ann - all watching Wendy go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy gets to her street, the Brown Sedan, parked as it always is on the side of the road with two people in it the windows fogging up. Wendy stops and looks at it, then knocks on the window. No answer. She knocks louder and then opens the door revealing an 18-year-old COUPLE. Her shirt is unbuttoned, his is off.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hey there!

dialogues.speaker: MAKE-OUT GUY
dialogues.text: What the hell-- Guy goes to shut the door, but Wendy is standing in the way.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to girl) That’s your boyfriend, right? (the girl says “Yes.” Wendy keeps going) You’re dating and all couply and you love him and he loves you and you’re thinking about babies and marriage or maybe Marriage and then babies or like a house and some furniture, right?

dialogues.speaker: MAKE-OUT GIRL
dialogues.text: (to guy) Shut the door.  73 11/4/05 78. But he can’t.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to girl) You know what’s totally fucked up? That you never hear anybody say that they are a girlfriend. They’re “my girlfriend.” That’s my dog, or that’s my car.

dialogues.speaker: MAKE-OUT GUY
dialogues.text: It is my car.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to Girl) You’re pathetic. You’re like this barely conscious amoeba willing to give away your identity for a penis to call your own. Wendy suddenly slams the door in the guy’s face.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into the window) I’d rather never have sex again than be you. She turns on her heel and stumbles toward home. INT. MAYER HOUSE: SEAN’S ROOM - NIGHT 73 Wendy watches Sean sleep. She doesn’t wake him up, but sits on the floor near his bed, looking at Sean’s hands. He opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hi. Sean, still half asleep, opens the covers but Wendy doesn’t move. Sean slides down and gets on the floor next to her.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It’s over?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No. But I’m all yours. Wendy smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Monday morning -- seen from above: Sean, Wendy and Nathan get into Wendy’s car and drive away. Helen comes out of the house and looks around, Abby is getting in her car and gives Helen a wave. Helen is left all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean and Wendy walk into school, holding hands. Wendy looks down at their hands entwined.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: This is okay?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It’s not too cute? Sean looks around. WENDY (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I’m just wondering who you are worried about seeing us hold hands. Wendy stops.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: This is hard for me. Be nice.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I am! A pause.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Be nice.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Fine. I’m being nice. He skips around her, still holding her hand. Wendy laughs until she sees Robert and Jonah walking into school behind them. She pulls Sean into the school, but he is still goofing off.  76 77 11/4/05 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean follows Wendy into the school, then throws his arm around her. Across the lounge, Wendy sees Billie and Ann, fighting. Billie grabs Ann’s arm, almost shaking her, she’s furious. Ann pulls away, and walks towards Wendy, who separates from Sean. Wendy and Ann face each other, but instead of talking to Wendy, Ann just stands in front of her, crying. There is a long pause as Wendy and Ann look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (softly) I hate you. Ann walks past Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy stands in the bathroom, trying to catch her breath and calm down. She looks in the mirror, pushes her hair forward so she can hide behind it. She gives herself a moment and then turns to go but standing in her way is Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You left.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Where’s Aaron? Wendy takes a step forward but Ryan doesn’t move and Wendy stops. There’s a pause and then Ryan throws her arms dramatically around Wendy. WENDY (CONT’D) Jesus. Ryan pulls away violently and holds Wendy at arms length.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You left. So now’s not the time to push people away.  11/4/05 81.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (still snide) Yeah? What’s it time for, Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You’re lucky. With me, Aaron was all I had once I left. But you have me, Aaron AND Sean.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (her attitude fading) How lucky for me.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I knew you would leave.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You don’t know shit. Ryan laughs. WENDY (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You just sound ridiculous when you swear. You always did. Wendy laughs, relaxing a little. RYAN (CONT’D) You’re here. You’re out.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What’s up with those shoes? Ryan looks down at the heels.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Aaron likes them.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I like doing nice things for him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Why’d you quit Amnesty? And Student Government?  11/4/05 82.

dialogues.speaker: . RYAN
dialogues.text: _.._ (lying) Billie. I wanted my afternoons free.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You quit for Aaron, didn’t you? Ryan sighs.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You know how he hated waiting around for us every afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So you quit? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Sean’s great.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: we’re comparing boyfriends?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Come out with us.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Come on. It’1l be fun. Wendy pushes past Ryan, and goes back out into the school. Sean is waiting for her, and they walk off, arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan is standing at the back door, holding a Cruset pan that is steaming. Pulling back a little we can see Bill is looking down at him, a strange and confused look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Is Helen here?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (persistent) Can you tell her Nathan is here?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: This isn’t a good-- (of the dish) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Glazed salmon and a risotto. I promised when I got it right, she could have it sO... Bill is seeing that the kid is smitten.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Listen, Nathan? wWe’re kind of in the middle of something here so if you could uh... I guess leave that here? Ora message.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Maybe you could just tell her--

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I have to get back inside. He reaches for the pan, and Nathan reluctantly gives it up. Bill is almost inside.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (after a beat) You’re welcome.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. For the salmon.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill kicks the door shut hard and then sees that HELEN HAS BEEN STANDING THERE THE WHOLE TIME.  80 11/4/05 84.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: An overgrown hobbit just delivered a salmon to our door.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You are such a shit.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He’s a nice kid.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: we’re in the middle of you hating me. So I’m sorry if our marriage took precedence over Iron Chef.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He’s my friend.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (whining) He’s fourteen years old!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He’s very helpful. Bill looks at her, he is trying to decide what she means, but Helen is heading out the door.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: To do what I always do, fix what you broke. Helen goes out the back door, turns around so she can see Bill’s reaction as she slams the door in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen turns and Nathan is right there, still in her backyard, waiting for her. He has been listening to Helen and Bill fight.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (completely maternal) You have nothing to be sorry for.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry you’re married to him. Helen laughs and then Nathan joins in. Her laughter dies down and so does his -- were their ages closer together or this a different world, they would kiss now. But instead. NATHAN (CONT’D) I should go inside. I’m glad you’re feeling better. Helen is silent, overwhelmed by Nathan’s grace and maturity; even Nathan is a little overwhelmed by the moment. He walks in his own back door Helen turns to go back into her own house. INT. BERGMAN HOUSE: WENDY’S ROOM - NIGHT 81 Wendy stands in the middle of her room holding a phone in her hand. She starts to dial and then puts the phone down. She tries again, but then stops. She puts the phone away and sits on her bed, opening a book. She lies on her stomach, then on her back, then she kicks off her shoes, she scooches around on her bed. She closes the book, then opens it up again, but doesn’t read. Then she just sits there. Alone. And doesn’t know what to do. She stands and we follow her to Nathan’s room, but his door is locked. Wendy stands, alone, in the hallway. She looks lost in her own home -- which of course she is. Wendy hears something downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy comes into the kitchen, trying to act nonchalant and takes out some ice cream and a spoon and absently eating. Abby is unpacking a tote bag full of work and carries a briefcase; she has a laptop set up in the kitchen. Wendy watches, just relieved for the company.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hey.  11/4/05 86. Wendy offers her mom some ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Thanks. They eat in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (trying) Work was good. I thought I’d try being here for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We’re fine. You’re not missing much.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I’m a terrible cook anyhow. Good thing your brother learned. Though he charged eight hundred dollars worth of salmon this week. Salmon isn’t the new dope, is it?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Dope?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (she finishes the ice cream and takes it to the garbage) Did you see our new neighbors?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (carefully) Yeah. We met them, like weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: How many of “them” are there?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Mom, dad and son. They seem nice. Sean -- he’s in my ethics and my Greek lit class. (pause) I think school tripped him out

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Is he cute?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Every mother dreams her son will fall in love with the girl next door.  11/4/05 87.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (trying to keep control) I’m not the girl next door

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You’re not a traditional girl next door true. You still have something special. She goes to push Wendy’s hair off her face. Wendy ducks away from her touch.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Sorry. I got lost in the moment. It won’t happen again.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You’re so needy.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (hurt) Thanks. Wendy gets up and goes. She turns and looks at her mom sitting alone. She feels bad.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t you look at me like that. I’m not to be pitied.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Every time you look at me I think you’re tallying up all the things I don’t have.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m not--

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I’m just a lot happier than you give me credit for. (she smiles) Where are the girls tonight? Wendy doesn’t answer so Abby goes back to work, and after a moment, Wendy leaves.  11/4/05 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy comes out of her house, breathes deeply and sits on the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy opens the door to find Jonah standing there.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Hey. You look nice.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Thanks. An awkward moment, and then he hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: You’re okay, right?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: He didn’t put some sort of voodoo spell on you, did he? Wendy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Good. A beat. JONAH (CONT’D) I wanted to leave once. Before Ryan and Aaron even.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Too chicken, I guess.  85 86 11/4/05 89.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (choosing her words carefully) For a...guy?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You can go anywhere next year. Or you could leave now.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Are you having fun?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Anyway, I just wanted to tell you I was proud of you. It was brave. Stupid, but brave. I wish I could have done it, but...whatever. (he smiles at her) I made a choice. Nobody’s fault, right? Jonah hugs her again, holding her close.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I miss you. Wendy watches Jonah walk away. EXT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: FRONT DOOR - NIGHT 85 Match cut to Robert’s front steps, where Billie and wendy usually sit. INT. BILLIE’S CAR - NIGHT 86 Billie and Ann sit in Billie’s car outside Robert’s house. Billie is looking at the front stairs. Ann starts to cry softly.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Fuck her. Ann keeps crying.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you? Ann opens the car door and tries to leave. Her seatbelt is still on. She removes it and then runs from the car, leaving the door open. Billie reaches over and slams the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you, too. Billie sits there, watching Robert’s house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has already left for the day. Sprinklers start up and spray the lawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy gets to her locker, then realizes that Billie is standing nearby. Wendy doesn’t look at her right away.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Your friends, all of us, we don’t want to let you go. And we won’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (quietly) What if I want to? Billie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: If you were a mom, and your kid was about to lose a limb, wouldn’t you, I don’t know, fight to keep it?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don’t think this is the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: But we feel it is.  11/4/05 91.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (starting to get angry) You’re speaking for everyone now?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. I think this is you, being lost and frightened and you don’t know what else to do. Billie doesn’t respond, she just reaches into the bag and pulls out WENDY’S BOX from Robert’s house. She drops it on the ground in front of Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I think your queer ass boyfriend would really dig this, huh? I was thinking of putting it in his locker. A little after- track-practice surprise. Wendy goes for it but Billie is faster and she holds onto the box.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (calmly as possible) You know what? Go ahead. It doesn’t work like that with us. Even better, why don’t you give it to him in class. Because even if you posted it on the internet and took out billboards, he wouldn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I think he’s gonna like the pictures from this summer especially. Billie opens her mouth very wide and does a pretty good oral sex simulation. Wendy remains calm.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Do it then. Don’t talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: And the ones of you on all fours. I mean, it probably makes more sense in context, you know, with the pictures of all of us, but still--  89 90 11/4/05 92. Wendy grabs the box from Billie’s unsuspecting hands marches over to Sean’s locker, takes her car keys and easily pries open the weak metal. The locker opens and she shoves the box in. Then she closes it again.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He wants me and that kills you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Not so far.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m not the box, Billie. And you are. You’re a pathetically limited little bitch, aren’t you? Billie reaches over and opens Sean’s locker again. Then she shuts it hard so it locks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: I was thinking of teaching your brother how to kiss. You know, train him up right. For future generations of Coop chicks. Wendy lunges at her but Billie moves away quickly and Wendy lets her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean is standing in front of his locker, which is open. He has WENDY’S BOX in one hand, the lid on the ground. We still don’t see into the box, but we see the Polaroids, just corners of them, some of them look like porn and some of them look like regular high school candids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy opens the door and looks around for Sean.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Sean? She doesn’t hear anything, then she hears a BASKETBALL being bounced in the backyard.  91 11/4/05 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen is trying to shoot some baskets, she misses completely and Wendy retrieves the ball for her

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Hi. Wendy holds the basketball for a second. HELEN (CONT’D) I think he’s upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: --okay. Wendy shoots a basket, it bounces back to her, and she hands the ball to Helen who makes a wobbly attempt. Instead of leaving her alone, Wendy decides to help.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stand here. Helen obliges, and readies her shot

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t bend so much. Aim the fingers of your bottom hand toward the back of the rim. Helen tries it, and makes basket.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That wasn’t bad.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You know that girl in school who always says she has her period so she doesn’t have to go to gym? That was me. Wendy smiles at her. Helen and Wendy trade off shooting baskets. HELEN (CONT’D) In school, I figured I would always be that girl -- the smart one, the one who was bad at sports. But it didn’t last. That person today, the person you saw, it wasn’t really me either. Or it was me and I’m not that person anymore. It was me for a moment. That was the me who gets an abortion. And now she’s gone. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just didn’t know I would be re- inventing myself so much when I grew up. You figure that when you’re young is when you re-invent yourself -- but it turns out that it is forever. You’re forever being a new you, in a new life, with new consequences.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I guess. Maybe you only think you’re new. Maybe you’re the same, only you don’t know it.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: That’s depressing.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah. But probably true. Helen pushes forward.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (struggling) If he... I mean if you...I know you guys have a..closeness. And that maybe you tell him things or want to tell him things--

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m not lying to him. Helen is surprised, but tries to hold it back

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It’s not a lie if you don’t tell him about something that happened.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: How is it not a lie? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (exhausted) I don’t know. She sits down on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Was your husband sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He apologized, if that’s what you mean.  11/4/05 95.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He did it on purpose though. He wanted to talk about it more.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Did you tell him he can talk about it when he gets pregnant? Helen laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t work like that when you’re Married. You don’t always get to say the meanest, most clever thing. Wendy throws a couple more baskets, not looking at Helen.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What’s it like?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Being married? It’s like...I don’t know if I can say it the right way, I mean, what’s it like to have a family? Try and explain it to me.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Custom made pants.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (laughing, not expecting an answer ) What?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It’s like custom made pants. They fit you perfectly but you can’t change. Not even a little.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Only sometimes. Honestly. It isn’t always like that. Is Sean pushing for...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No. No, it’s not Sean. It’s the whole “girlfriend” thing.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: The identity. Being someone’s “girlfriend”.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You have to be something else first. The only way to be with someone is to be someone. Wendy hands the ball to her.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Sean’s inside? Helen nods. INT. MAYER HOUSE: SEAN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 92 Wendy walks into Sean’s bedroom which is empty. She hears water running in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hello? Inside the bathroom, Sean is getting out of the shower Wendy opens the door and knocks him down. Sean tries to get up and Wendy goes to help him when she sees HER BOX on the floor, the contents clearly rifled through, water dripping over it from the shower. Her first instinct is to save the valuable contents from getting wet so she grabs the stuff.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. God forbid the kiddie porn gets wet.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That’s not what’s in here.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is all puppies and “I love unicorns” and tapioca pudding.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It’s not porn. It’s just--

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: They made you do it, right?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Screw you.  11/4/05 97. Sean doesn’t say anything, he just sits on the lip of the tub. WENDY (CONT’D) Do you want me to go? Sean shrugs. Wendy reaches out and takes his hand to get him to stand. He pulls it away so she gets down on the floor and takes his wet hand and puts in to her lips. Then she kisses each finger. She kisses his palm, and then his wrist. Sean doesn’t pull away.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t know how this works. I mean, do we fight now? Tell me what we do.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: We don’t do anything. Wendy pauses.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (trying to make a joke) So this is what being dumped feels like, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) You’d have to be mine for me to dump you huh?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What? What do I do? You wanna yell at me? I’m lost--

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: That’s enough. You don’t get to play the little innocent girl right now. Not after-- (gestures to the box) No way.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You know what? It happened. You want it to go away, like magic? Poof, and now I’m all different? I’m magically a virgin?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wendy laughs, but Sean doesn’t  11/4/05 98.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You’re kidding, right?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: No. Burn the box. Burn it all.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You’re delusional. why don’t you burn all the stuff from your old girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t have stuff. That’s the point.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You’re insane.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Why? Do you need this stuff? I mean does it have any value?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m not saying it has value. But it’s what? Letters? A couple of trinkets? She holds up the “Hoochie” necklace.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This? Some pictures of me naked? You’re acting like you’re pure and virginal.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Compared to this?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Really? What was the name of the blowjob girl?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: From the party? Billie told me. The girl who went down on you?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You believe what Billie says? Besides that is completely--

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Please. Don’t be average. It isn’t different. Either you agree to be in this with me, or you don’t.  93 11/4/05 99. Sean pulls his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (pissed off) --fine.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You could just forget it? If I burned it, you would just forget that I was ever someone else. She isn’t sure what she was, so she just stops.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I could stop being reminded, couldn’t I? Wendy looks at him for a beat. He puts his hand out for her to kiss again, to seal the deal. She kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School is over, and everyone mills around, grabbing books, screaming at each other. It’s chaos. The doors are open, it’s a warm fall afternoon and students have started throwing/chucking buckeyes (like large acorns) at each other. Sean and Wendy walk with Ryan and Aaron as they get their things from their lockers.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: So you’11 come on Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: A double date. With Ryan and Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (focusing on Sean) Yeah, of course. Wendy doesn’t see Billie walk by.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It’1l be fun. (lowers his voice) And tonight we do it, right? You’1l burn the box tonight? Wendy notices Billie.  11/4/05 100.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (not listening) Yeah, okay. Billie looks lost without Ann or Wendy, but straightens her back and walks to the soda machines, feeds in her dollar. Some buckeyes are thrown at her. She doesn’t flinch. More are thrown. Still, Billie doesn’t move. Finally a barrage of buckeyes are raining down on Billie. She flinches when one hits her in the face. Wendy watches, unable to move.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (it is killing her) Say something. Do something.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Not you. Her. Billie finally turns and leaves, never looking at Wendy, never reacting. As she leaves, the other seniors clap.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: That is insane. Wendy doesn’t say anything, and Sean goes back to his locker. Wendy waits a moment and then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I have to see if she’s okay. Sean grabs her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Everyone will see you.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: She’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Billie can take it. Wendy pulls her arm away, and then stands, looking out at the sea of students, wanting to run after Billie, but not sure if she should.  94 11/4/05 101.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m not going to burn it. I’m not going to say I’m sorry for what happened.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down. Wendy’s suddenly past the “voice down”/decorum place.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: And I’m not going to apologize. You either love me, or you don’t. I just gave up five of the best people in the world for you.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Who you slept with.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So what? So what if I slept with them? They matter to me. And I just walked away and destroyed my life because you walked up with all this...

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Love. It’s called love. You don’t want to say it, fine. But that’s what I offered you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You offered me a role in your fairy tale. That’s all. Sean doesn’t know what to say. So Wendy makes a decision for both of them.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t want me to be your girlfriend. INT. BILLIE’S CAR - DAY 94 Billie sees Wendy in the rearview mirror. Billie smiles, she can’t help it. And she reaches over and unlocks the passenger car door. Wendy gets in.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You remember Miss Hise’s class? Wendy smiles, carefully.  11/4/05 102.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We tortured her daughter, Greer.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: She carried those bookbags.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: She smelled terrible.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: And then in third grade, when my parents split up, and I decided, I don’t know why, to do a dance, from that movie, Flashdance. You remember?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (starting to laugh) We saw it on cable.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (laughing with her) I can see the third grade me, and she’s getting up to do that dance, and I want to tell her to stop. I’m embarrassed right now, just talking about it. Their laughter fades but the moment was real.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your friends, all of us, we don’t want to let you go. Wendy doesn’t respond right away.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It can’t be like before. I need to know it’11 be--

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: That I won’t be so evil?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m asking for small changes, not miracles. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You wanna hug me, bitch? Billie laughs, and does. Wendy notices the welt from the buckeyes, and touches it. Billie pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You gotta do one thing though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sound. Billie and Wendy walk toward the school, Wendy is looking ahead of her, Billie is looking at Wendy. At first we see them close up and then we are inside the school, watching them as they walk towards the front glass doors, and when they finally get there, and they open them, we hear the chatter and background of the school again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie and Wendy stand in front of Ryan, Aaron and Sean. The milling stops. Everyone stares. There’s a long incredibly uncomfortable pause.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Hi! Wendy doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wwe’re scaring you?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You’re disturbing us. Billie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Well, gosh, we’re sorry. (to Wendy) Do it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (slowly) Did she tell you where the scar came from?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) Do it. Ryan looks stricken.  11/4/05 104.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: All the girls knew. We never told the guys about dear old Uncle Rob--

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: It was Uncle Bob.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Uncle Bob who smelled like Aqua Velva and tasted like Doritos.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (can’t resist) That dear old Uncle Bob liked to touch her. And that one time he actually had her for a whole weekend.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Shut up. Shut up you bitches. You can’t stop me. I don’t care what you say. (her ace) Aaron knows everything. Ryan is looking at Wendy, imploring her. RYAN (CONT’D) (to Wendy) Don’t.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to Billie) Let’s go, okay? Billie?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Everything? (smiles broadly) Aaron, did you know that Ryan here. She liked it. She liked the pain. She liked to be held down and forced. Made her all-- Billie turns to Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: What did it make her? Wendy? Wendy takes a deep breath, then turns to Billie.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (small) Hot.  11/4/05 105. Billie smiles triumphantly. There’s a beat. POV WENDY: She sees Sean, Ryan, Aaron, Billie. A crowd of people. Everyone in the school.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like when you used to make us play gang rape. Where we had to be the firemen.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: That wasn’t me. Wendy is looking at Billie. Everyone is looking at them.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Or how you kept cutting yourself with Exacto knives during art class. How you thought you were a vampire for most of eighth grade.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (almost a growl) Stop.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Or how Jonah and Robert have been sleeping together for three years. Or how Ann’s mom tied her hands together so she wouldn’t touch herself when she was six. (Wendy starts getting giddy) Or how I peed during a spelling bee in third grade. Or how Aaron threw up when you got your period in fifth. Or the time we all got crabs because Price fooled around with some girl over Christmas break. Yeah, we’re one big happy family-- Billie has left the lounge. Wendy turns to Sean.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Burn the box yourself. I don’t need it anymore. Wendy walks out of the school.  97 98 99 100 11/4/05 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy smiles as she walks. For the first time, there is no hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floodlights make everyone look kind of greenish as they leave their mall jobs.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN GIRL
dialogues.text: (wearing a “Gap” name tag) I fell in love with this guy once and it was complete torture. He kept wanting to hug me all the time. I’m like, are you nine years old? What the hell is that? Hugging and stuffed bears. Like he read about it at the Hallmark store. You know how many successful actresses are married? (makes zero with her fingers and then smiles) He did give me this though-- She walks up to the camera and shoves her hand in the dens, so we catch a distorted glimpse of exactly what a mall job will buy at Zales. TEEN GIRL #11 (CONT’D) I got to keep this. Nice huh? LEGEND: This Is Saturday EXT. ROBERT’S HOUSE: FRONT DOOR - DAY 99 A series of shots, as in the beginning of the film. Robert carefully places four boxes on the front step takes his own, passes one to Jonah and the two go back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, standing in front of a Weber grill in his backyard, burning the contents of the box. He puts the “Hoochie” necklace in his pocket.  101 102 103 11/4/05 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The House Party, with the porn, the drinking, the girls making out with other girls. Ann is giving a guy a pole dance with a blank look on her face. We track through the same party, and the Tank-Top Girl #1 from the first party pulls Price into a bedroom. INT. BILLIE’S HOUSE: ROOM - NIGHT 102 Billie has the box open in front of her but we don’t see her face, as she sits on the floor of her room. Laid out on the floor, encircling her, are various mementos. She lays each one out carefully, in some order we are not privy to. She smooths a few pictures, she carefully places a lighter next to an old license plate. As we circle the items, we catch a passing glimpse of Billie, who might be crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy sits on the kitchen counter watching Nathan cook She is holding a wooden spoon and Nathan hands her a mixing bowl, so Wendy mixes. She kicks her legs absently against the wooden cabinet and then kicks her shoes off. The camera pulls back, leaving the room, so we see Wendy framed in the doorway, Nathan walks out and it is just Wendy alone and happy, a dopey half smile on her face, as the credits start to roll.
